content:
2 as a result is quite an edge case.
I would suggest not having it only in the validators. (Validator 1)
I think it's better to add some specific limits for n. For example, n <= 1000.
This problem might also become an interesting puzzle if it allows much larger inputs that require more efficient algorithms.

Given a number n, print the biggest â€œhighly composite numberâ€ less than **or equal** to n

When I ignore the "or equal" part, I still pass all testcases but fail validator 2. I'd like to see a visible testcase where it fails as well.

"4 -> 1*2*4: 3"
A '*' isn't the best choice to separate divisors.

My bruteforce solution in C# passes all the tests well within the time limit.
The same code in python passes the visible tests but fails the final validator.
1. The validator should never be harder than the test (checking for timeout)
2. I'd like to either see a lower or higher time limit, so that python can pass in O(N^2) too or to enforce a faster algorithm for compiled languages too. 15k gives an advantage for some languages.
Honestly a "factor" can easily be confused with a "prime factor", please use the word "divisor" instead.
Sure, Thanks for letting me know
Thank you so much, I will work on it

That's a good idea! Can I make both puzzle and clash of code? I'll change a few requirements here and there but ya, I'll allow for larger inputs. But in order to do that, I first have to optimize my codeðŸ˜…. It doesn't work beyond 10k.
Is the current limit n <= 7000 too high?
I would love to but there aren't many test cases under 1000

I wrote solution that has complexity of O(n^2) and it passed all test cases. I suppose itâ€™s fine if you leave it as it is now. The only reason I said 1000 is because usually Python can handle ~10^6 operations per second. Assuming the time limit letâ€™s Python to pass all test, everything should go good.

I think so. I have a question,  I am actually a beginner and I don't know much about time complexity and how to calculate our program's time complexity. If you don't mind Can you please share a good resource where I can learn about it. Sorry to bother you and Thanks a lot for your comments and Thanks a lot for approving this problem.
I think this might be a good start: https://www.khanacademy.org/computing/computer-science/algorithms#asymptotic-notation

I just did this in a clash and the brute force approach passed all tests as mentioned above. The solution works until 10k. Some minor improvements can get it work until 200k. Serveral players were able to implement a solution within a few minutes so I think that limit is good for CoC.

n = int(input())
max_m = max_i = 0
for i in range(1,n+1):
    m = sum(i%j==0 for j in range(1,i+1))
    if m > max_m:
        max_m = m
        max_i = i
print(max_i, max_m)

you can also substitute m = sum(i%j==0 for j in range(1,i+1) by, m = sum(i%j==0 for j in range(1,int(i**.5)+11)) + 1
Doing so we can reduce the second loop by square root of i operations and then add 1 for ith divisor. you know what I mean? Ya, thanks for letting me know.

Using i**.5 is what I referred to as "minor improvement". You need some special treatment when i is a square number though. The correct implementation is like this:

d = int(i**.5)
m = sum(i%j==0 for j in range(1,d + 1)) * 2
if d * d == i:
    m -= 1

Idk but the guideline does not seem to forbid that. You might ask in the forum or directly send a message via https://www.codingame.com/about/contact to confirm about that. At the first glance, I think a more efficient algorithm for this problem is to generate the sequence of highly composite numbers having 1, 2, 3, ... divisors using dynamic programming. You might also change the input / output for the puzzle to directly ask for the nth highly composite number.
Definitely, Thanks a lot

I would have been totally fine with factor, as it usually stands that product = factor * factor, and yes thats the reason its even callen prime factor. There is nothing misleading about it.

But its also fine calling it divisor I guess....
